Special foodie events make dining spots even more attractive 1 / 2 Back to Gallery It's been nearly a month since Alison Cook 's Top 100 for 2015 was revealed. If you're looking to knock a few off your dining bucket list, here are some reasons to visit now.
No. 10, Caracol
Caracol, one of Cook's Top 10 Houston restaurants, celebrates oyster season with a menu full of beautifully prepared bivalves. Among them: Ostiones a la Lena (smoked oysters wrapped in bacon) for $11 and Taquitos de Ostion (fried oyster tacos with chipotle mayonnaise) for $11. Or you could indulge in champagne and oysters. Caracol offers a bottle of Mumm's Cordon Rouge Champagne and half-dozen of roasted Gulf oysters for $65. 2200 Post Oak, 713-622-9996
No. 29, Kitchen 713
Kitchen 713 has begun hosting weekly Thai pop-up dinners 4-9 p.m. Mondays for a project it is calling Chaam Noodles. Call to confirm times and menu. 4515 Canal, 713-239-2498
No. 36, Izakaya
Izakaya, the Midtown Japanese tapas bar, recently launched a happy hour from 5-7 p.m. daily. In addition to $6 premium sakes and select cocktails, happy hour comes with a small-bites menu that includes house-made venison hot dog, quail Scotch eggs and fried fish nuggets, all priced at $6. 318 Gray, 713-527-8988
No. 37, Peska Seafood Culture
The restaurant has launched a Sunday brunch buffet that includes a paella station, raw bar and bottomless mimosas and sangrias. The buffet is offered 11 a.m.-3:30 p.m. and costs $45 ($18 for ages 10 and younger). 1700 Post Oak, 713-961-9229
No. 76, Sylvia's Enchilada Kitchen
Sylvia's offers a handful of cooking classes at its Energy Corridor location. Upcoming classes include appetizers (Saturday), chiles rellenos (Nov. 7) and tamales (Nov. 14, Dec. 5 and Dec. 12). The hands-on classes are 12:30-3 p.m. and include a full meal and a signature magarita. Most classes are $65. Reservations are essential. 1140 Eldridge , 832-230-3842
